item.title: Datacamp Course 4
item.description: DataCamp Course: Building Web Applications in R with Shiny: Case Studies by Dean Attali Here is the link to the assigned course. For this DataCamp course, you‚Äôll learn more about shiny using hands on case studies. The instructor for this course is a shiny expert who‚Äôs shinyjs package helps blend JavaScript code snippets within Shiny. He also has a great advanced shiny blog post that provides a lot of great tips for more customized functionality.

Coral: an R shiny and D3.js web app for flexible, interactive, and high-resolution visualization of the human kinome. https://t.co/xD7QUXgjOR pic.twitter.com/1gGy9zzsBT ‚Äî doug phanstiel (@dphansti) May 25, 2018

item.title: Design Contest Presentations
item.description: Contents Slides Slides No lecture/slides today; we‚Äôll have each group present their design contest presentations (10 minutes for each group).

item.title: Problem set 3
item.description: Task 0: Getting started Create a new RStudio project somewhere on your computer. Open that new folder in Windows File Explorer or macOS Finder (however you navigate around the files on your computer), and create a subfolder there named output. Download this R Markdown file and place it in your newly-created projectYou‚Äôll probably have to right click on the link and choose ‚ÄúSave link as‚Ä¶‚Äù. It contains an outline/skeleton of the one task you‚Äôll need to do in this problem set.

item.title: Unstructured text
item.description:
Required Chapter 1: Tidytext format and Chapter 3: Analyzing word and document frequency: tf-idf in Julia Silge and David Robinson, Tidy Text Mining in RJulia Silge and David Robinson, Text Mining with R (Sebastopol, California: O‚ÄôReilly Media, 2017), https://www.tidytextmining.com/. Recommended Chapter 6: Topic modeling in Julia Silge and David Robinson, Tidy Text Mining in RIbid.
Ken Benoit, Kohei Watanabe, and Stefan M√ºller, ‚Äúquanteda‚Äùquanteda is my favorite R-based text package.

item.title: Datacamp Course 3
item.description: DataCamp Course: Building Web Applications in R with Shiny by Mine Cetinkaya-Rundel Here is the link to the assigned course. For this DataCamp course, you‚Äôll learn about shiny, the framework for developing html-based interactive visualizations without requiring HTML, CSS, or JavaScript experiment (though it will help tremendously if you have a background).

item.title: Design contest
item.description: Datasets: Choose from one of four datasets. babynames: US baby name data for each year from 1880 to 2013, the number of children of each sex given each name. All names used 5 or more times are included. 1,792,091 rows, 5 columns (year, sex, name, n, prop). (Source: Social security administration). fueleconomy: Fuel economy data for all cars sold in the US from 1984 to 2015. 33,442 rows, 12 variables.

item.title: Statistical Models
item.description: Contents Tweet of the day Overview Lab 6: Work with models in ggplot2 Tweet of the day At long last, the parsnip package is on CRAN. parsnip is a unified R interface to models. The first of two blog posts about the package is at https://t.co/PXgFJ8eucM #rstats #tidyverse pic.twitter.com/BmuA9exckK ‚Äî Max Kuhn (@topepos) November 28, 2018 Overview No slides for today‚Äôs class. Design contest assignment.

item.title: Statistical Models
item.description: Required Chapter 6: Work with Models in Healy. Chapter 22: Model introduction and Chapter 23: Model basics in Wickham/Grolemund. Recommended Chapter 6: Basic Regression from ‚ÄúModernDive: An Introduction to Statistical and Data Sciences via R‚Äù by Chester Ismay and Albert Y. Kim.This is an outstanding new book ‚Äì with a free online version ‚Äì that will be a big complement to the tidyverse in the future.

item.title: DSBA 5122: Visual Analytics
item.description: class: center, middle, inverse Defining Uncertanity and Risk Knightian Uncertainty, a la Donald Rumsfeld Gigerenzer Separates the use of heuristics, or rule-of-thumbs class: middle, center, inverse Bayesian theory class: middle, center, inverse Safari example Overview Set-up: We‚Äôre on safari in South Africa and we want to see the lions. Problem: We‚Äôre uncertain to the lions‚Äô location. Application: How can we design a visualization tool to aid our driver to help find the lions?

item.title: Distributions & Uncertainty
item.description: Contents Tweet of the Day: Slides: Links: Lab: Tweet of the Day: My ??? talk is now in video form: A biased tour of the uncertainty visualization zoo. If you liked the version with just slides, you'll love (?) the version with me talking over slides :) https://t.co/hSdczZlgKW ‚Äî Matthew Kay (@mjskay) December 7, 2018 Matthew Kay is an assistant professor of Information at the University of Michigan School of Information.

item.title: Distributions & Uncertainty
item.description:
Required Chapters 7 and 11 in Alberto Cairo, The Truthful ArtAlberto Cairo, The Truthful Art: Data, Charts, and Maps for Communication (Berkeley, California: New Riders, 2016).
Chapter 7: Histograms and density plots, Chapter 8: Empirical cumulative distribution functions, Chapter 9: Visualizing many distributions at once and Chapter 16: Visualizing uncertanity in Claus Wilke, Fundamentals of Data VisualizationClaus E. Wilke, Fundamentals of Data Visualization (Sebastopol, California: O‚ÄôReilly Media, 2018), https://serialmentor.

item.title: Time & Space
item.description:
Required Chapter 8: ‚ÄúRevealing Change‚Äù and Chapter 10: ‚ÄúMapping Data‚Äù in Alberto Cairo, The Truthful ArtAlberto Cairo, The Truthful Art: Data, Charts, and Maps for Communication (Berkeley, California: New Riders, 2016).

Her textbook ‚ÄúVisualization Analysis and Design‚Äù is one of the most popular data viz books and some of her former students are now leaders in data viz (e.

item.title: Visual Representation Basics II
item.description:
Required Chapter 6: ‚ÄúExploring Data with Simple Charts‚Äù in Alberto Cairo, The Truthful ArtAlberto Cairo, The Truthful Art: Data, Charts, and Maps for Communication (Berkeley, California: New Riders, 2016).
Chapter 4: Show the right numbers in Kieran Healy, Data VisualizationKieran Healy, Data Visualization: A Practical Introduction (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 2018), http://socviz.co/.
Recommended Chapter 5: Directory of visualizations and Chapter 22: Image file formats in Claus Wilke, Fundamentals of Data VisualizationClaus E.

item.title: DSBA 5122: Visual Analytics
item.description: class: center, middle, inverse The Truth Continuum (Chapter 3) ‚ÄúAny visualization is a model.‚Äù ‚Äì ‚ÄúThe more adequately a model fits whatever it stands for without being needlessly complex, and the easier it is for its intended audience to interpret it correctly, the better it will be.‚Äù class: center, middle class: center, middle class: center, middle class: center class: center, middle class: center, middle ‚Äì ‚ÄúGood visualizations shouldn‚Äôt oversimplify information.

item.title: Visual Representation Basics I
item.description: Contents Tweet of the day Slides Helpful Materials esquisse: ggplot2 add-in Tweet of the day Visual encoding is itself a data transformation, often applied after a chain of other transformations. This is ‚Äúfirst week of class‚Äù, table stakes stuff. Sad if true that we don‚Äôt internalize this! ‚Äî Jeffrey Heer (@jeffrey_heer) August 11, 2018 Enrico Bertini is a data visualization researcher at NYU who co-hosts (with Moritz Stefaner) the podcast ‚ÄúData Stories‚Äù, which I highly recommend.

item.title: Visual Representation Basics I
item.description:
Required Chapter 3: ‚ÄúTruth Continuum‚Äù and Chapter 5: ‚ÄúBasic Principles of Visualization‚Äù in Alberto Cairo, The Truthful ArtAlberto Cairo, The Truthful Art: Data, Charts, and Maps for Communication (Berkeley, California: New Riders, 2016).
Chapter 1: Look at data in Kieran Healy, Data VisualizationKieran Healy, Data Visualization: A Practical Introduction (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 2018), http://socviz.co/.
Recommended Chapter 2: Aesthetic mapping in Claus Wilke, Fundamentals of Data VisualizationClaus E.

item.title: DSBA 5122: Visual Analytics
item.description: class: center, middle Welcome Introduce yourself Name What‚Äôs your academic and professional background? Programming & visualization experience (e.g., tools like R, Tableau, Spotfire, etc.) What are you interested in learning more about with data visualizations? To do by next class: Send me an introduction email rwesslen@uncc.edu answering these questions. It‚Äôs up to you on length. This is my chance to learn about your background.

item.title: Datacamp Course 1
item.description:
DataCamp Course: Introduction to the Tidyverse by David Robinson Here is the link to the assigned course. For this DataCamp course, you‚Äôll learn about using tidyverse package from David Robinson, Chief Data Scientist for DataCamp.David is a prolific data scientist and blogger, whose blog ‚ÄúVariance Explained‚Äù is one of the most popular data science blogs. He has a great blog post discussing the background of this course.
This course has four chapters:

item.title: Intro to Visual Analytics
item.description: Required Given this is the first class, there are no required readings. Questions to reflect on How do we know what is true? Are facts truth? Why do we visualize data? What makes a great visualization? How do you choose which kind of visualization to use?

item.title: Introduction to Visual Analytics
item.description: Contents Tweet of the day: Slides & Lab Tweet of the day: Any time I have been struggling to learn a new tool/technology/software ‚Ä¶ I go back to this short clip I cut out of ???'s 2014 ??? tutorial on Dplyr to motivate myself to keep pushing through ‚Ä¶ learning new tools is hard for everyone at the beginning! pic.twitter.com/RevpkSJqWc ‚Äî Aliakbar Akbaritabar (Ali) (@Akbaritabar) July 25, 2018 Hadley Wickham is the R guru amongst gurus.

item.title: Truth, beauty, and data revisited
item.description: Required Chapter 12 in Alberto Cairo, The Truthful ArtAlberto Cairo, The Truthful Art: Data, Charts, and Maps for Communication (Berkeley, California: New Riders, 2016). Chapter 24 in Claus Wilke, Fundamentals of Data VisualizationClaus E. Wilke, Fundamentals of Data Visualization (Sebastopol, California: O‚ÄôReilly Media, 2018), https://serialmentor.com/dataviz/. Ben Wellington, ‚ÄúMaking data mean more through storytelling‚Äù Jonathan Schwabish, ‚ÄúBetter Data Communication,‚Äù National Bureau of Economic Research Why People Make Bad Charts (and What to Do When it Happens) Questions to reflect on Questions TBD

item.title: Enhancing graphics
item.description: Required Chapter 15, Chapter 16, Chapter 18, Chapter 20, and Chapter 21 in Claus Wilke, Fundamentals of Data VisualizationClaus E. Wilke, Fundamentals of Data Visualization (Sebastopol, California: O‚ÄôReilly Media, 2018), https://serialmentor.com/dataviz/. Chapter 8 in Kieran Healy, Data VisualizationKieran Healy, Data Visualization: A Practical Introduction (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 2018), http://socviz.co/. Other readings TBD Questions to reflect on Questions TBD

item.title: Enhancing graphics
item.description: Required Chapter 15, Chapter 16, Chapter 18, Chapter 20, and Chapter 21 in Claus Wilke, Fundamentals of Data Visualization [@Wilke:2018] Chapter 8 in Kieran Healy, Data Visualization [@Healy:2018] Other readings TBD Questions to reflect on Questions TBD

item.title: Enhancing graphics
item.description: Required Chapter 15, Chapter 16, Chapter 18, Chapter 20, and Chapter 21 in Claus Wilke, Fundamentals of Data Visualization [@Wilke:2018] Chapter 8 in Kieran Healy, Data Visualization [@Healy:2018] Other readings TBD Questions to reflect on Questions TBD

item.title: Annotating and grouping
item.description: Required Chapter 17 and Chapter 19 in Claus Wilke, Fundamentals of Data VisualizationClaus E. Wilke, Fundamentals of Data Visualization (Sebastopol, California: O‚ÄôReilly Media, 2018), https://serialmentor.com/dataviz/. Chapter 5 in Kieran Healy, Data VisualizationKieran Healy, Data Visualization: A Practical Introduction (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 2018), http://socviz.co/. Other readings TBD Questions to reflect on Questions TBD

item.title: Problem set 5
item.description: The instructions for this problem set will be posted at least one week before it is due.

item.title: Text
item.description: Required Look through some of the chapters in Julia Silge and David Robinson, Tidy Text MiningJulia Silge and David Robinson, Text Mining with R (Sebastopol, California: O‚ÄôReilly Media, 2017), https://www.tidytextmining.com/. (but definitely don‚Äôt read them all! You just need to get a taste of what modern text analysis looks like.) A bunch of (really) short things: Julia Silge, ‚ÄúShe Giggles, He Gallops‚Äù Abby Ohlheiser, ‚ÄúThese are the words most associated with men and women, according to Facebook status updates‚Äù Six Ideas for Displaying Qualitative Data Word clouds considered harmful Word clouds cause death‚Ä¶ or something When It‚Äôs Ok to Use Word Clouds The Class of 2011 Every time Ford and Kavanaugh dodged a question, in one chart Sentiment Analysis of The Book of Mormon Tweet by @s_soroka Questions to reflect on Why is qualitative data difficult to visualize?

item.title: Networks and Trees
item.description: Required Chapter 10 in Alberto Cairo, The Truthful ArtAlberto Cairo, The Truthful Art: Data, Charts, and Maps for Communication (Berkeley, California: New Riders, 2016). Chapters 2-9 in John Coene, Twinetbook It looks like this is a lot of reading, but lots of these are short videos or tweets or interactive websites, so don‚Äôt worry! Why all world maps are wrong The True Size Of‚Ä¶ Map projections Gall-Peters Projection ‚ÄúWhen Maps Lie‚Äù Animated Mercator distortion ‚ÄúThese Twisted Maps Prove That America Isn‚Äôt a Red Country‚Äù ‚ÄúThe next great fake news threat?

item.title: Time
item.description: Required Chapter 8 in Alberto Cairo, The Truthful ArtAlberto Cairo, The Truthful Art: Data, Charts, and Maps for Communication (Berkeley, California: New Riders, 2016). The Nuclear Threat‚ÄîThe Shadow Peace, part 1 11 Ways to Visualize Changes Over Time ‚Äì A Guide A bunch of (really) short blog posts: Streamgraphs: Economic trade flows with R A century of ocean shipping animated What is seasonal adjustment and why is it used?

item.title: Assignments
item.description: DataCamp Courses You will need to complete four DataCamp courses, each is 2.5 points. Points will be allocated for all (2.5 points) for completion or 0 points (not completed) by the assigned date. These will be assigned on DataCamp and are intended to reinforce the programming assignments and material. About half-way through the semester (February-March), additional DataCamp courses may be provided for extra credit points. Problem sets To practice working with RStudio and making data-based graphics, you will complete a series of 4 problem sets.

item.title: Final projects
item.description: Contents Helpful links For their final projects, students will develop their own Shiny app to develop an interactive visualization on an interesting data-intensive problem. Helpful links Mike Kearney‚Äôs list of 3,000+ Shiny Apps shared on TwitterThis site is a great place to start for getting motivation. Find someone else‚Äôs app. Look at their code. Get ideas of what can improve their visualization. Learn new ways to present data.

item.title: Installing R, RStudio, and tidyverse
item.description: You will do all of your visualization work in this class with the open source (and free!) programming language R. You will use RStudio as the main program to access R. Think of R as an engine and RStudio as a car dashboard‚ÄîR handles all the calculations and the actual statistics, while RStudio provides a nice interface for running R code. RStudio.cloud R is free, but it can sometimes be a pain to install and configure.

item.title: Reference
item.description: Contents Citations and bibliography Interesting and excellent real world examples How to select the appropriate chart type Helpful data visualization resources Visualization in Excel Visualization in Tableau Information Visualization & Visual Analytics Courses Working with R and ggplot2 R in the wild Data Pulling your own data: Past datasets: Colors Fonts Markdown Citations and bibliography ⊕You can open the file in BibDesk on macOS, JabRef on Windows, or Zotero or Mendeley online.

item.title: Schedule
item.description: Here‚Äôs your roadmap for the semester! Readings should be completed before each class session Assignments are due by 11:59 PM on the day they are due Class materials (slides, in-class activities, etc.) will be added on the day of class Information Visualization Reading Assignment Class January 14 Intro to Visual Analytics January 14 Datacamp course 1 (Due Jan 29) January 21 No class (MLK Holiday) January 28 Visual Representation Basics I January 28 Problem set 1 (Due Feb 11) February 4 Visual Representation Basics II February 4 Datacamp course 2 (Due Feb 19) February 11 Time & Space February 18 Distributions & Uncertainty February 18 Problem set 2 (Due Mar 11) Interactive Visualizations Reading Assignment Class February 25 Statistical Models February 25 Design Contest assigned (Due Mar 25) February 25 Datacamp course 3 (Due Mar 12) March 4 No class (Spring Break) March 11 Multidimensional & Dimensionality Reduction March 18 Text-as-Data March 25 Design Contest Presentations March 25 Problem set 3 (Due Apr 8) April 1 Networks and Trees April 1 Final project assigned (Due May 6) April 1 Datacamp course 4 (Due Apr 16) Advanced Topics Reading Assignment Class April 8 Coordinated Multiple Views: Interacting & Brushing April 15 Deployment, Back-end and Scalability April 15 Problem set 4 (Due Apr 29) April 22 Machine Learning April 29 Wrap-up Final Reading Assignment Class May 6 Final project due

item.title: Syllabus
item.description: Data rarely speaks for itself.⊕Instructor Ryan Wesslen CenterCity rwesslen@uncc.edu @ryanwesslen Office Hours via Calendly Course Mondays January 14 ‚Äì May 6, 2019 6:00‚Äì8:45 PM Room 110M: Packard Place Slack By itself, the facts contained in raw data are difficult to understand, and in the absence of beauty and order, it is impossible to understand the truth that the data shows. In this class, you‚Äôll learn how to use industry-standard graphic and data design techniques to create beautiful, understandable visualizations and uncover truth in data.
